Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Herbivore interactions and plant responses: from foliar chemistry to communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to understand how two invasive insect pests, the woolly adelgid and the hemlock scale, affect eastern hemlock trees. The woolly adelgid has devastated entire forests of hemlock along the east coast of North America, but the hemlock scale -- which is just as common -- has had minimal impact. Although common sense indicates that two pests are worse than one, research suggests the opposite. Intriguingly, trees infested with elongate scale seem somehow protected from the adelgid. Understanding why this happens and whether 'inoculation' with one pest might protect the tree from another type of pest requires understanding how trees defend themselves and respond to attack. Researchers have teamed up on a project that uses a combination of experiments and mathematical models to develop a 'road map' of plant responses to forest pests. Specifically, they will assess how each pest affects plant defenses and nutrient storage.

Given the economic and ecological losses caused by many species of insect pests, it is tremendously important to develop a detailed understanding of how forests are impacted by (and might be protected from) multiple pests. By identifying the response pathway, the results of this study can be applied to other systems to predict the likely impact of multiple herbivores on forest health. This project also provides an opportunity for urban schoolchildren to learn more about nearby forests. The researchers have developed a partnership with SMILE (Science and Math Investigative Learning Experiences), a locally-based group that offers enrichment activities to children from poorly-performing school districts. Graduate students and SMILE staff will work with teachers to develop and implement a year-long educational module on forests and food webs. Funding provided by this award will be used to pay for field trips to local forests to help students learn about these systems and survey hemlocks for the presence of invasive pests.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Most research into plants and the insects that eat them (herbivores) tends to focus on the impact(s) of a single type of insect on a plant of concern. In nature, however, plants often attacked simultaneously by several different types of insects.  The impacts of a particular insect type differ if one vs. several types are present on a plant at the same time. Recognizing the importance of these insect-insect interactions for plant health provides an “expanded perspective” on species interactions that can help us better understand their large-scale consequences. Our research sought to understand the interactions occurring between two invasive insects that differ greatly in their effect on a native host, eastern hemlock (Tsuga canadensis). The leaders of this collaborative project were Colin Orians at Tufts University and Evan Preisser and Carol Thornber at the University of Rhode Island.

We examined the effects of two invasive herbivores, the hemlock woolly adelgid (Adelges tsugae) and elongate hemlock scale (Fiorinia externa) on eastern hemlock. Both insects are very small (<1.5mm, or 0.05 inches) and are sessile (e.g. do not move) for most of their life cycle; their invaded ranges overlap in the northeastern United States. In this region, the adelgid has caused widespread hemlock mortality and negatively impacted forest health.  We quantified the effects of these insects at different levels, from mechanistic studies in the laboratory to landscape-level analyses.  In the laboratory, we examined the response of adelgids to plant foliage that had been attacked by scale, or treated with plant hormones that mimic insect attack.  We also examined how these insects affect growth and tissue chemicals of hemlocks, and how they interact with soil microbes (i.e., mycorrhizae critical to plant health).   Finally, we conducted insect density field surveys in hemlock forests across New England to measure patterns of association (e.g. are both insects common in the same forests?) and used the data to build mathematical models to predict the density of insect pests over time.

We found that adelgids significantly harm hemlock trees.  They slow plant growth, delay bud break (emergence of new branch buds during spring), and cause dramatic shifts in many chemical traits.  For example, adelgids raise the nitrogen content of hemlock needles, which benefits adelgids while reducing the nitrogen that is available to the plant (for growth). Adelgids also alter the abundance of soil microbes. Scale insects, in contrast, had little effect on the hemlock or the soil microbes.  Despite the minimal impacts of the scale, we observed effects that could not be predicted by single-species studies. Although adelgids weaken trees and make them more suitable to scale, the presence of scale can deter adelgids from attacking the same plant.  When these results are combined with our previous research, we find that the impacts of scale differ on young vs. mature hemlock trees. In summary, the severe impact that adelgids have on hemlock could lead to the loss of this important tree in the landscape.

Broader Impacts

This award led to the training of post-doctoral fellows, graduate students and many undergraduate students. We trained two postdoctoral associates in experimental design and analysis, collaborative science and data management, and student mentoring, skills critical for their future careers. We also trained four graduate students and over a dozen undergraduate students. They were involved in the entire process of science, from experimental design to publication.

In addition to training, our work led to numerous publications in peer-reviewed journal, talks to the general public, and presentation to our peers and stakeholders at regional governmental workshops and at national and international meetings.

Lastly, this grant supported SMILE (Science and Math Investigative Learning Experiences, http://web.uri.edu/smile/). SMILE is an after school academic enrichment program (grades 4-12) run by the University of Rhode Island (see supporting photo).  It is designed to encourage under-represented minorities and disadvantaged students in the STEM fields, to help them maintain good grades and encourage them to go to college. During the course of the grant, SMILE students participated in annual Family Science Nights, annual environmental/career-oriented fieldtrips, and annual events including the 4th grade URI Ecology Field Day and 5th grade Elementary Outdoor Science Adventure.
